questions.text: Cardiomyopathy is a disease of the heart muscle that makes it harder for the heart to pump blood to the rest of the body. Cardiomyopathy can lead to heart failure. The main types of cardiomyopathy include dilated, hypertrophic and restrictive cardiomyopathy. Cardiomyopathy may be seen in all the following except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alkaptonuria Cardiomyopathy is seen in all the above conditions except Alkaptonuria. - Option A, B and C. GSD 2 is also known as Pompe disease and is associated with CM, CM is absent in GSD 5 also known as McArdle’s disease.

questions.text: An athlete fainted in the middle of the marathon and complained of palpitations and chest pain. On examination, pulsus bisferiens and ejection systolic murmur are noticed. The echo shows septal thickness. Which of the following is NOT true about the cause?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the leading cause of sudden death in the young

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Characterized by misalignment and disarray of the enlarged myofibrils and myocytes

options.label: D
options.text: Biopsy is needed to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questions.correct_answer: D. Biopsy is needed to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biopsy is needed to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy A biopsy is NOT needed to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy but can be used to exclude infiltrative and metabolic diseases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It is the leading cause of sudden death in the young and is an important cause of heart failure. Option: B. Although the pediatric presentation is associated with increased early morbidity and mortality, the prognosis for patients diagnosed as adults is generally favourable. Option: C. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by misalignment and disarray of the enlarged myofibrils and myocytes, which can also occur to a lesser extent in other cardiac diseases.

questions.text: With a normal left ventricular end-diastolic pressure of 5 mm Hg, a 20-mm Hg gradient produces a left atrial pressure of 25 mm Hg. Left atrial pressure rises even further as flow across the valve increases (increased CO). This high left atrial pressure backs up and floods the lungs. So, this can be inferred that the Left atrial filling pressure closely approximates the:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure Left atrial filling pressure closely approximates Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) PCWP is an increase in cardiac pulmonary oedema but it is normal in non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Central venous pressure - Central venous pressure, which is a measure of pressure in the vena cava, can be used as an estimation of preload and right atrial pressure. Central venous pressure is often used as an assessment of hemodynamic status, particularly in the intensive care unit. Option: C. In physiology, intrapleural pressure refers to the pressure within the pleural cavity. Normally, the pressure within the pleural cavity is slightly less than the atmospheric pressure, which is known as negative pressure. Option: D. Right atrial pressure (Pra) is determined by the interaction of the function of the heart as a pump, which is called cardiac function, and the factors that determine the return of blood to the heart, which is called return function.

questions.text: A young football player collapsed during a match and regained consciousness several minutes later. He gives a history of similar episodes before. His elder brother had died suddenly at the age of 22 years during a football game due to a heart ailment. Which of the following is least likely to be found on echocardiography in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction

options.label: B
options.text: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve

options.label: C
options.text: Mitral regurgitation with anteriorly directed regurgitant jet

questions.correct_answer: C. Mitral regurgitation with anteriorly directed regurgitant jet
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitral regurgitation with anteriorly directed regurgitant jet The given clinical scenario of exercise intolerance (syncope) in the patient and the family history of sudden cardiac death in his elder brother at a young age are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Mitral regurgitation with the posteriorly directed regurgitant jet is usually seen on the echocardiogram in HCM. ECG and echocardiogram are used to confirm the diagnosis of HCM. HCM is characterized by myofiber disarray in the heart, resulting in a hypertrophic myocardium.

Highyeild:

The hypertrophy leads to the following: pathophysiological changes in HCM: Diastolic dysfunction - presenting as exercise intolerance Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve The hypertrophied muscles result in a narrow outflow tract This leads to the production of a high-velocity jet pulling the mitral leaflets towards the septum posteriorly. SAM leads to mitral regurgitation Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction Echocardiography features of HCM are as follows: Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm The hypertrophied heart is more confined to the Interventricular septum resulting in the banana-shaped ventricular cavity So, Options A, B and D all are correct .

questions.text: While auscultating a young man for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy you hear a harsh and late-peaking systolic ejection murmur at the lower left sternal border. On performing which of the following manoeuvres, the intensity of this murmur expected to decrease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Squatting Squatting increases the preload and afterload thereby decreasing the outflow obstruction and intensity of murmur in HCM. In HCM left ventricular size is small, thus the approximation of the interventricular septum with the mitral valve increases. The following mechanisms further increase this approximation and increase blood outflow obstruction and intensity of murmur: A decrease in left ventricular cavity volume or pressure (decreased preload) A decrease in systemic vascular resistance and/or arterial pressure (decreased afterload) Increase in left ventricular contractility The image below shows a cross-section of a heart with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 17-year-old Chinese boy presented with prolonged fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in his legs. His echocardiography was suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies can explain his condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Selenium The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency . It is endemic dilated cardiomyopathy that affects children and women of childbearing age in some areas in China. So toxicity is known as Kashinbeck disease.

Highyeild:

keshan's disease (can be assc with cox B virus) endemic cardiomyopathy seen in selenium deficiency c/f cardiogenic shock, CHF, cardiac enlargement rx: reversible on sodium selenite supplementation kashin beck disease selenium deficiency c/f osteoarthropathy and necrosis of joints and epiphyses seen in pre adolscents and adolscents

Manganese - The very limited evidence in humans suggests that manganese deficiency might caus e bone demineralization and poor growth in children; skin rashes, hair depigmentation, decreased serum cholesterol, and increased alkaline phosphatase activity in men; and altered mood and increased premenstrual pain in women Option: C . questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of syncope. ECG is suggestive of LV hypertrophy. A Doppler echocardiography revealed abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Digoxin The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy , Digoxin should be avoided as it may increase contractility and worsen obstruction.

Highyeild:

Drugs that can lead to possible aggravation of outflow tract obstruction and thus contraindicated in HCM are: Digoxin Inotropes Nitrates ACE inhibitors

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Beta-blockers and verapamil are first-line agents in the treatment of HCM Option: C. Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg- nifedipine, amlodipine) Option: D. Disopyramide and amiodarone are the preferred antiarrhythmic agents.

questions.text: A 50 yr old lady presents with complaints of dyspnea on exertion and abdominal discomfort. She also mentions H/O undergoing multiple radiation therapy for Ca Breast, 12yrs ago. A PET scan shows no metastasis. On examination, JVP rises with inspiration and along with that increased liver span and pedal oedema are noted. Low voltage ECG is seen along with a Square root wave sign in Doppler ECHO. Which of the following is incorrect about the disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased LV diastolic dimension Restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM)is the diagnosis here. In this case, radiation exposure is an important aetiology and the clinical features point towards its diagnosis . It is characterized by diastolic dysfunction with restrictive ventricular physiology, whereas systolic function often remains normal. Atrial enlargement occurs due to impaired ventricular filling during diastole, but the volume and wall thickness of the ventricles are usually normal. + L.V diastolic dimension is the presentation of DCM , but not in RCM

Highyeild:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy General examination findings: Increased jugular venous pressure Decreased pulse volume Ascites and pitting oedema of the lower extremities Hepatomegaly due to fluid or amyloid infiltration Easy bruising, periorbital purpura, macroglossia, and other systemic findings (eg, carpal tunnel syndrome) may be evidence of amyloidosis Cardiovascular system examination findings: Normal S 1 and S 2 heart sounds, with a normal S 2 split Loud early diastolic filling sound (S 3) A fourth heart sound (S 4) is almost never present Murmurs due to mitral and tricuspid valve regurgitation (usually not hemodynamically significant) Respiratory system examination findings: Breath sounds are often decreased due to pleural effusions, frequently bilateral and large in amyloidosis Crepitations or rales are rarely heard

In RCM L.V wall thickness is either be or Normal but never t ↑ wall thickness , present in HOCM. Option: C . Due to fibrosis ejection fraction will reduce.

questions.text: A multiparous P3L3 young lady who delivered normally 3 weeks ago suddenly developed dyspnea with cardiac failure. She has no H/O cardiac disease before /during pregnancy. She had tachycardia and peripheral oedema. Her haemoglobin was 9 gm/dl. Her Echo has revealed an EF of 35%. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary embolism

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peripartum cardiomyopathy Peripartum (postpartum) cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is defined as an idiopathic cardiomyopathy that presents with heart failure secondary to left ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction toward the end of pregnancy or in the months after delivery, in the absence of any other cause of heart failure.

Highyeild:

PPCM is diagnosed when the following criteria are met: Heart failure - develops in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months of delivery Heart pumping - function is reduced, with an ejection fraction (EF) of less than 45% No other cause for heart failure with reduced EF can be found. In this question anaemia, MI and Pulmonary embolism have been ruled out.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Acute MI- Ruled out as chest pain at rest, elevated cardiac markers or ECG changes are not present. Option: B. DVT with PE -Develops suddenly and is a close answer but the point against is Echo finding of only a low ejection fraction. In PE, Echo shows RV dyskinesia with or without tricuspid regurgitation. The interventricular septal deviation is also seen Option: C. Amniotic fluid embolism -Ruled out as it occurs immediately during active labour.

questions.text: Dilated cardiomyopathy is a type of heart muscle disease that causes the heart chambers to thin and stretch, growing larger. Which of the following drugs is not given in dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcium channel blocker Nifedipine-like CCBs are contraindicated in HOCM. Any agent that decreases preload is contraindicated. Also; verapamil’s concomitant use with beta-blockers is contraindicated.
